content: The "Border Health Security Act of 2013" may be cited as the official title of this Act. Key findings are outlined in Section 2. The United States-Mexico border region has over 15 million people facing public health challenges like low health insurance coverage, limited access to healthcare, high unemployment, and prevalent diseases. The 2009 H1N1 pandemic highlighted the need for strong public health efforts at borders to protect Americans and enhance biosecurity. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission has addressed cross-border health issues for 11 years. Over 75 percent of Canadians live within 100 miles of the US border, as seen during the 2003 SARS epidemic near New York. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is being amended. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is being amended to cooperate with the Canada-United States Pan Border Public Health Preparedness Council and serve as an independent body to recommend and implement initiatives for border health issues. The Chair of the Council shall be the leader. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act is being amended to cooperate with the Canada-United States Pan Border Public Health Preparedness Council. Members of the Commission and the Council may provide advice or recommendations to the Secretary, Congress, or any Member of Congress regardless of a request or authorization. Section 8 is redesignated as section 12, and section 7 is replaced with new provisions. "Border Health Grants are addressed in Section 7 of the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act." The term 'eligible entity' includes various organizations serving vulnerable communities in border areas. Grants will be awarded to these entities to address priorities outlined in the strategic plan. The eligible entities in border areas can apply for grants to implement programs related to maternal and child health, primary care, infectious disease testing, and public health as outlined in the strategic plan. Application requirements and fund usage guidelines are specified by the Secretary. The curr_chunk discusses various areas of focus for grants in border areas, including public health, health promotion, oral health, behavioral and mental health, substance abuse prevention, workforce training, and community health workers. It also addresses health conditions prevalent in border areas and healthcare infrastructure issues. The curr_chunk focuses on health disparities, environmental health, health education, outreach services for Federal programs, trauma care, infectious disease research, epidemiology, and cross-border health surveillance in border areas. The curr_chunk discusses cross-border health surveillance, obesity, crisis communication, violence prevention, and public health preparedness programs. Amounts provided for grants should supplement, not supplant, other funds available to carry out the activities. The curr_chunk discusses grants for early warning infectious disease surveillance in the border area. The term 'eligible entity' includes various organizations for grants in early warning infectious disease surveillance in border areas. Eligible entities can apply for grants and must use funds for surveillance activities in coordination with state and local programs. The curr_chunk discusses the development and implementation of infectious disease surveillance plans, coordination with US-based agencies and authorities in Mexico or Canada, improving infrastructure and laboratory capacity for detecting potential infectious diseases. The curr_chunk outlines measures to enhance the detection of infectious diseases, including creating a health alert network, educating healthcare professionals, implementing data systems for incident coordination, providing testing in border areas, and conducting other identified activities. The curr_chunk mentions carrying out additional activities as identified by various authorities and border health offices. SEC. 9. PLANS, REPORTS, AUDITS, AND BY-LAWS. The Commission and the Council must prepare a binational strategic plan every 5 years to guide their operations, including health-related priority areas and recommendations for goals and objectives. The Commission and the Council must develop a strategic plan every 5 years with recommendations for addressing priority areas, goals, objectives, strategies, and actions. They also need to create an operational work plan and budget based on the strategic plan, with evaluations conducted by the Comptroller General every 2 years. The Council evaluates operational work plans and output indicators from the previous year. Biannual reports with policy recommendations on border health issues are submitted to the Secretary. The Secretary prepares an annual audited financial report for appropriated assets. The Commission and Council must develop bylaws within 6 months of enactment to ensure compliance with the requirements. They are required to submit operational work plans, by-laws, and evaluation reports to Congress. "SEC. 10. COORDINATION." Plans, systems, and activities funded under this Act for all hazard preparedness and border health must be coordinated with authorities in Mexico, Canada, and the United States. The Secretary may establish a health alert system to notify of disease clusters, health threats, extreme weather, disasters, and bioterrorism along the borders. The Act funds preparedness for disasters, bioterrorism, and emerging threats along the United States borders with Mexico and Canada. "Authorization of appropriations for disaster preparedness, bioterrorism, and border security along the US borders with Mexico and Canada." Authorized appropriations of $7,000,000 annually for the Act, with $4,650,000 for functions, activities, and grants related to the US-Mexico border and border health activities. $2,350,000 allocated for US activities on the US-Canada border and border health authorities. The Act authorizes annual appropriations of $7,000,000, with $4,650,000 for US-Mexico border activities and $2,350,000 for US-Canada border activities. It includes definitions for terms like 'Indian', 'Indian tribe', 'tribal organization', and 'urban Indian organization'. The term 'United States-Canada border area' is defined as the area within 100 kilometers of the border between the United States and Canada.
